Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Advancing a Novel Low-voltage Electric Arc Method to Oxidize Organic Material in Contaminated Water
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will support the final development and commercialization of Symbios Technologies plasma treatment system to allow produced water in the oil and gas industry to be effectively treated, thereby allowing its safe discharge to surface waters or recycling to stimulate production in new wells, rather than being disposed of in injection wells. Produced water is the water brought to the surface, with or without hydraulic fracturing, along with the intended fuel products during extraction of oil, gas, and coal bed methane from formations underground. In general, produced water is contaminated with hydrocarbons, salts, and harmful microorganisms, meaning that it must be treated before it can be discharged or reused for agriculture and other purposes. This is an important environmental, public safety, and economic problem in the US. Research conducted during this project will be used to evaluate reactor improvements including process sensors and control systems, electrode geometries and surface coatings, degradation of contaminants in produced water, field testing, and techno-economic modeling. The anticipated technical results are that the Symbios plasma system will degrade hydrocarbon contaminants and kill microorganisms in frac flowback or produced water, leaving the waters suitable for safe reuse or discharge.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that it will facilitate cleanup and reuse of a critical resource, water, in the oil and gas production industry, with crucial societal benefits for protecting the environment, guarding human safety, and keeping domestic energy costs down. The proposed technology is based on an innovative, low-voltage plasma discharge that creates powerful oxidizing species for destroying biological and chemical contaminants in produced water. Symbios Technologies has developed relationships and executed agreements with key companies in the produced water treatment field, which have identified numerous near-term business opportunities and provided crucial insights into preparing the technology for commercial success during Phase II. The customer-centered emphasis on solving water contamination problems in the oil and gas industry, which was estimated to have a global market size of $45 billion in 2010, will result in a high likelihood for commercial success. The Phase II R&D plan will enhance scientific and technical understanding as well as commercial impact by addressing reactor improvements pertaining to corrosion resistance and automated operation for a market-ready system, treatment of microbial and organic contaminants in produced water, on- site testing, and demonstration of economic competitiveness of the developed system.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project generated advancements in the systems, methods, and uses of aqueous plasma technology to clean water polluted with organic contaminants. Current water treatment methods suffer from high carbon footprint and cost, inability to remove certain key contaminants effectively, generation of waste streams, and reliance on toxic chemicals with safety, transportation, and need for removal issues. Water treatment providers and end-use customers seek treatment solutions that address these shortcomings, and much attention has focused on plasma and electrochemical systems in recent years. Symbios Technologies has developed the tunable, modular, and scalable Symbios Tubular Plasma Reactor (TPR™) to address these challenges by reducing carbon footprint of water treatment, minimizing energy consumption, and cleaning water without toxic chemicals or waste streams.

 

These are some of the main outcomes from this Phase II SBIR project:

  • We established that the Symbios TPR™ enabled plasma treatment of aqueous solutions at lower energy demand, reduced carbon footprint, lower cost, smaller footprint, and without need for chemicals vs. other water treatment systems and previous attempts at plasma systems due to its innovative patented design.
  • We proved treatment efficacy and demonstrated commercial treatment cost and flow rates for multiple contaminants of interest working with water treatment channel partners and end-use customers across microbial and organic contamination in a variety of actual samples including power plant cooling tower water (findings published in D.C. Johnson et al., An innovative non-thermal plasma reactor to eliminate microorganisms in water, Desalination and Water Treatment: 1-12 (2015)), oil and gas produced waters, food processing rinse waters, landfill leachate, and industrial and domestic wastewaters.
  • We optimized design and developed a fully automated rack-mounted prototype TPR4000™ model with automated power and volume/flow control, data logging, safety interlocks, and fully integrated user interface.
  • We used techno-economic and cost estimation modeling tools to generate engineering design and cost estimates for commercial-scale TPR4000 systems for multiple applications driven by market demand in manufacturing, utilities, oil & gas, and healthcare sectors.
  • We discovered that the TPR also can be used in drug discovery applications to manufacture Aqueous Plasma Chemotherapeutics (APC) for oncology and infectious disease indications, and published an article on this topic (J.M. Joslin et al., Aqueous Plasma Pharmacy: Preparation Methods, Chemistry, and Therapeutic Applications, Plasma Medicine, 6(2): 135–177 (2016)).

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2020
Modified by: Justin Bzdek

Current water treatment methods suffer from high carbon footprint and cost, inability to remove certain key contaminants effectively, generation of waste streams, and reliance on toxic chemicals with safety, transportation, and need for removal issues. Water treatment providers and end-use customers seek treatment solutions that address these shortcomings, and much attention has focused on plasma and electrochemical systems in recent years. Symbios Technologies has developed the tunable, modular, and scalable Symbios Tubular Plasma Reactor (TPR™) to address these challenges by reducing carbon footprint of water treatment, minimizing energy consumption, and cleaning water without toxic chemicals or waste streams. These are some of the main outcomes from this Phase II SBIR project: We established that the Symbios TPR™ enabled plasma treatment of aqueous solutions at lower energy demand, reduced carbon footprint, lower cost, smaller footprint, and without need for chemicals vs. other water treatment systems and previous attempts at plasma systems due to its innovative patented design. We proved treatment efficacy and demonstrated commercial treatment cost and flow rates for multiple contaminants of interest working with water treatment channel partners and end-use customers across microbial and organic contamination in a variety of actual samples including power plant cooling tower water (findings published in D.C. We optimized design and developed a fully automated rack-mounted prototype TPR4000™ model with automated power and volume/flow control, data logging, safety interlocks, and fully integrated user interface. We used techno-economic and cost estimation modeling tools to generate engineering design and cost estimates for commercial-scale TPR4000 systems for multiple applications driven by market demand in manufacturing, utilities, oil & gas, and healthcare sectors. We discovered that the TPR also can be used in drug discovery applications to manufacture Aqueous Plasma Chemotherapeutics (APC) for oncology and infectious disease indications, and published an article on this topic (J.M.
